summary: David G. Marwell served as the Executive Director of the Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB) during its active period from 1995 to 1997. While not always explicitly named in the documents, his role placed him at the center of the ARRB's interactions with agencies like the CIA, particularly concerning the declassification and release of JFK assassination records. He was involved in negotiating the release of sensitive information, including the identities of CIA employees and covert operations. Marwell also received information and addressed concerns regarding the sensitivity of specific records, such as those pertaining to joint US-Mexican intelligence operations, as evidenced by memos from individuals like John Pereira.
significance: High - As the Executive Director of the ARRB, David G. Marwell played a crucial role in the declassification and release of JFK assassination records. His involvement in negotiations with the CIA and handling of sensitive information highlights his significance in this historical context. The number of documents (18) associated with him further underscores his importance.
